title: 114_s1714
content: The "Miners Protection Act of 2015" includes certain retirees in the multiemployer health benefit plan. Section 402 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to include provisions for transferring beneficiaries to the plan and calculating excess based on enrolled beneficiaries. The Miners Protection Act of 2015 allows for the transfer of beneficiaries enrolled in the Plan who are eligible to receive health benefits, including those defined as payable following death, retirement, or disability in the bituminous coal industry under a coal wage agreement. The Miners Protection Act of 2015 allows for the transfer of beneficiaries eligible for health benefits under the Plan, even in cases of bankruptcy. Retirees are considered eligible for health benefits, and the transfer amount is reduced by any funds used to pay Plan benefits. The Miners Protection Act of 2015 allows for the transfer of beneficiaries eligible for health benefits under the Plan, even in cases of bankruptcy. The administrator of the voluntary employees' beneficiary association must transfer any amounts received from the bankruptcy proceeding to the Plan, minus administrative costs. Additional amounts may be calculated based on the dollar limitation. The Miners Protection Act of 2015 allows for the transfer of additional amounts to the 1974 UMWA Pension Plan if the dollar limitation exceeds the required transfers. Transfers will cease once the plan's funded percentage reaches 100 percent. The 1974 UMWA Pension Plan can receive transfers to reach at least 100 percent funded. No amendments increasing plan liabilities can be made during receiving transfers unless required for IRS qualification. Transfers under the plan affect withdrawal liability under ERISA. Transfers made under subparagraph (A) for the 1974 UMWA Pension Plan are disregarded in determining unfunded vested benefits and employer withdrawal liability. Transfers must maintain contribution rates at least as high as those in effect 30 days before the Miners Protection Act of 2015. The Miners Protection Act of 2015 requires the trustees of the 1974 UMWA Pension Plan to file an annual report with the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, including documentation on the plan's financial status. The Miners Protection Act of 2015 mandates annual reporting on the UMWA Pension Plan's financial status, including details on funded percentage, actuarial value of assets, and market value of plan assets. The annual reporting on the UMWA Pension Plan's financial status includes details such as contributions, benefits paid, cash flow projections for the upcoming years, and funding standard account projections. The annual reporting on the UMWA Pension Plan includes projections for the plan year and the following 9 years, assumptions for these projections, total investment gains or losses, any significant reduction in active participants, and a list of employers that withdrew from the plan. The annual reporting on the UMWA Pension Plan includes projections for the plan year and the following 9 years, assumptions for these projections, total investment gains or losses, any significant reduction in active participants, and a list of employers that paid withdrawal liability to the plan during the preceding plan year. This list includes the total assessment of the withdrawal liability paid, the annual payment amount, and the number of years remaining in the payment schedule for each employer. Additionally, any material changes to benefits, accrual rates, or contribution rates during the plan year are also reported. The annual reporting on the UMWA Pension Plan includes details on contribution rates, scheduled benefit changes, funding improvement plans, and participant numbers from the preceding plan year. The annual reporting on the UMWA Pension Plan includes participant and beneficiary numbers, details from the most recent annual funding notice, Department of Labor Form 5500 information, and copies of the plan document and amendments. The annual reporting on the UMWA Pension Plan includes participant census data, distribution of benefits, actuarial valuation report, collective bargaining agreements, and financial reports as required by the Secretary of Labor or Treasury. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation must electronically submit an annual report to the Treasury and Labor Secretaries. Failure to file the report on time incurs a $100 daily tax on the 1974 UMWA Pension Plan. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation imposes a $100 daily tax on the 1974 UMWA Pension Plan for late filing of the annual report, unless reasonable diligence is shown by the trustees. The term '1974 UMWA Pension Plan' is defined in accordance with the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
